fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*

1. View a review in one browser as user A.
2. Mark file X as completed.
3. View the review in another browser as user B.
4. Have B raise a defect on X.
5. In A's browser, update the review from the review updated notice.

*Expected*
- After step 5, the defect should be inserted and, if user A has set the preference, file X should be marked as incomplete.

*Actual*
- The comment is inserted, but the file is *not* marked as incomplete.
fields.summary: Review updated defect insertion doesn't incomplete the file
Grammar issues in Not Complete notification

fields.summary: When a reviewers completion status changes, update the primary action if applicable

fields.description:
Archives Containing Over 65535 Files
Versions of Java earlier than v1.6 (b25) are incapable of handling zip files that contain more than 65,535 files. The solution for this problem is to either upgrade to a version of Java later than v1.6 (b25), or ensure that the archive does not exceed the threshold (contains less than 65,535 files). The FishEye cache (not included in backups by default) can be a contributor of many small files. Hence, exclude the cache from backups if this is likely to be a concern.

Archives Larger Than 4GB
Java has trouble reading and writing zip files that are larger than 4GB. As of release 1.5 Java appears capable of reliably creating archives that are over 4GB, but remains unable to extract them. For details see [Sun's bug report|http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4681995]. Also be aware of the fact that some file systems (including FAT32) have trouble with files larger than 4GB.
fields.summary: Address backup ZIP shortcomings

fields.description:
We are still plagued by the bug that will not die: creating a comment sometimes leaves ghost draft comments in a review.

* The are not visible in the ui. Everything seems okay - create comment, post, only one appears
* Refreshing the review will not show the draft comment
* Completing the review will show a warning _You have draft comments!_
** Viewing the draft comments will show the FRX where the draft lives, but it does not show
** Posting the draft comments will result in duplicated comments when reloading the review (since we have the originally saved comment, and the draft which has now been posted)

This has also been reported by a customer: [CRC-886|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CRC-866]
fields.summary: Crucible is still creating ghost draft comments

fields.description:
includes an overall percentage derived from the progress of all reviewers (and/or possibly another "train-track" with the review states)

incorporates the "time in state X" information & overdue information. Shown always on review page. See Brendan for mockup
There are some transitions (like Under Review to Summarise) where you want to indicate "progress" between states.  Think of this more as how far away from completion is the review.  A trainline where the stations are review states.  The distance between states seems to be variable, ie the under review state is the variable one.
Need to figure out how to handle abandon.  Should we indicate which state the review was in when it was abandoned.  Should we change the colour of the visualisation when the review is in different metastates.
The state of the review cannot be changed with this control.

fields.description: vendor lock-in :-D TRAC does it. should be optional per repo.  Commit message from repo are treated as wiki markup
fields.summary: Commit messages are wiki-rendered

fields.description: collapse at any level, whatever confluence does. leave auto collapsing to later.  No collapse/expand all at the review or file level.  No 'ahead of time' collapsing like confluence.
fields.summary: Provide a link at the top of any thread of comments to collapse the comments, like Confluence

fields.summary: Wording when all reviewers is/are complete is clunky.

fields.description: You need to be logged in to call this service so that when we expose this via REST anonymous can't call it.  Add subtask for REST
fields.summary: add UserService to SPI that gives User/Committer mappings, TZ info, Avatars, email, prefs

fields.description: !http://img.skitch.com/20090706-c7kyn2fw4g4muate3rmburnb44.jpg!
fields.summary: Don't list me as one of the completed reviewers if I've just completed the review

fields.description:
Single LEFT/RIGHT button pair, with a mouse-over drop down that controls which entities are navigable (FRXes, comments, defects). Also, careful attention needs to be paid to navigation button state. In the past, with FRX control, both are enabled when I come to a new review, even though there is no "previous" file.
No change to keyboard shortcuts
This is multi-select, by default all options are selected. 
We are not doing read/unread comments at this time
fields.summary: Replace FRX and comment navigation with super-navigation

fields.description:
related issue CRUC-1603

Ultimately, the ISO date string format is never visible to the user. For this story, add to the Edit Details / Due Date field ONLY
Remember that forms will need to post back in the ISO form with timezone translation happening on the browser
fields.summary: Use separate date and time fields for setting due dates, like google calendar.  We need a global widget across FE and CRU
in fullscreen mode, respect single-file mode

fields.description: UI only change
fields.summary: When I add myself to a review, I get notified that I've added myself to a review

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce

1) Create a crucible review with some files selected from a fisheye repository 
2) Stop the repository ( Administration > View Repository List > Stop (next to your REPO the review was created against))
3) Go back to the review, edit review and click on suggest reviewers 

You will get:

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Having an instance with more than 50 reviews.
2. Navigate to _Projects -> <project name> -> Reviews -> All_

Clicking on the page number of the review result in the same page. Please see the screenshot for a clearer picture: [page1|^page1.JPG], [page3|^page3.JPG]
fields.summary: Page number for the review does not work

fields.description:
With the iterative review feature (where multiple patches can be uploaded to the same crucible review) it's not immediately clear which file is up for review, since they all show up in the left panel as the same path/name.  A couple options for dis-ambiguating:

1) a simple indicator showing "this is the latest uploaded" version
2) showing the patch upload # next to each file when there are multiple patches on a review?
3) disable comments on previously uploaded versions and grey out the filenames in the leftpanel? (this might be excessive/undesired but it makes sense for my particular usecase)
4) (THIS ONE) seperate out each source as a divider/folder
fields.summary: Indicator needed for multiple versions of same file in review

fields.description:
We just upgraded from Crucible 1.6.6 to 2.0.2, with the intent of moving the Crucible database onto our database server (Postgres), and off HSQL. However, the migration failed several times due to the fact that in HSQL, there were no varchar size constraints, and so we had several rows in the HSQL database that contained data too large for some of the varchar(n) columns in the Postgres database.

I went through and tracked down the issues, manually updating the HSQL database to bring the data into compliance, but if the error message were clearer about what the actual issue was, it would've helped.

You can test this by creating a Review name (cru_review.name) longer than 255 characters using HSQL as the database and then attempting to migrate from HSQL to Postgres. Its also possible that there are now application level constraints on the length of the data, even in HSQL, so you may want to try with 1.6.6.
fields.summary: Error message when migrating from HSQL to PostgreSQL due to varchar constraints unhelpful at best.

fields.description:
Crucible 1.6.x was bad enough, but performance in version 2.0.2 is pathetic.

So far we have completed about 150 reviews since moving to 2.0.2 (very very painfully, I might add).

If the reviews had few files (30 or less) they would could be loaded viewed, and worked with "ok" - still quite sluggish, but workable.

However changesets that have over 100 files, and particularly those with over 700 files just make the application completely unworkable.

What's worse, once reviews with such changesets exist, working with other reviews becomes seriously impacted.  For example if I view a new changeset in fisheye, and then click "create a review", it takes many minutes for the create review dialog to appear.  I presume this is because crucible is searching for existing reviews related to the files in this new changeset, such that it can suggest reviews to add them to -- and that this search entails loading the large reviews that completely bog the system down.

Crucible seems to have very serious problems with data loading - it seems that it must be loading every bit of info about the review whenever any portion of the review is being looked at --- and that such loading is pathetically slow.

Also the web ui is very heavy.  A review that contains 700 files takes minutes to load into the browser and a quad-core 64-bit machine with 8 GB of RAM.   While loading Firefox complains that the script is taking too many resources, and do I want to stop it or continue?  I select continue and it churns for another long time, then asks the same question.  This repeats several times before the page is finally loaded.   Very large chagesets (e.g. 10,000 files) completely crash the system.


The end result is that the tool is pretty much useless on a large code base once a few changesets that apply to many files are submitted. (these large changesets are reasonable, real-world changesets:  e.g. new branches in perforce that contain thousands of files,  or changes to encoding roles, copyright notices, etc. on many files within a path).


We are running with the database externalized to PostgreSQL 8.4.0.   The server machine is running linux, quad core 64 bit processor, 8 gb ram.  I will do some more profiling to determine how "taxed" the machine seems to be while loading the large reviews, and post any further info I have that seems like it would be of use.

fields.description:
File Revisions that Are in Reviews are reported as Not Under or In Review.

We are seeing regular occurrences of this (e.g. at least 1 out of 20 reviews).

For a given changeset with N files (e.g. 30 files), we create a review.   Some subset of the files (e.g. 4 of them) still report as not reviewed (and as not under review).

Nothing we can do (including making more reviews for them) seems to make them report as reviewed.


Being able to determine what is reviewed and what isn't is CRITICAL to our projects for which government customers require that we be able to prove all code changes are reviewed.


For info, here is an example query, which improperly lists files that have in fact been reviewed (and if you look at the review, it very clearly shows these files).

{code}
select revisions from dir / where date >= 2009-08-01T06:00:00.00Z and not reviewed and not in any open,draft review and author = jhouse order by date desc group by changeset 
{code}


See attached screen shots (which has some sensitive details blurred) - 1- query and results,  2- review containing files in question
fields.summary: File Revisions that Are in Reviews are reported as Not Under or In Review
